name: NewYorker
text:
As the Republican National Convention begins in Charlotte, some former party stalwarts are working to peel G.O.P. voters away from the President.
https://t.co/UhtToeYAak

name: NewYorker
text:
In a series of portraits of herself and her daughter, Anna Grevenitis casts viewers as the strangers who often stare at and scrutinize her child.
https://t.co/EklRYtITGj

name: NewYorker
text: "Were Trump not running, I probably wouldn't be running," Joe Biden said. "He's so contrary to everything that I believe about government." Listen to Biden's interview with @eosnos on #NewYorkerRadio. https://t.co/HEsHn4eLIT

name: NewYorker
text:
In this week's episode of #NewYorkerRadio, we investigate why the killers of Ahmaud Arbery were allowed to walk free until the shooting became a national scandal.
https://t.co/knrm0xAZY5

name: NewYorker
text: For a Black woman to become a major party’s nominee for Vice-President is certainly evidence that some things have changed in the U.S., @KeeangaYamahtta writes. But it is surprising, if not ironic, that Joe Biden was the candidate to make this selection. https://t.co/sb02lG6Sc9

name: NewYorker
text: The failure of Donald Trump’s impeachment left Democrats with a sense of investigation fatigue and futility, but it’s not too late for them to adopt a strong anti-corruption campaign theme. https://t.co/OyBxCboSQw

name: NewYorker
text: The live-at-home approach suits Norah Jones, @Paul_R_Elie writes. It foregrounds her directness and natural musicianship, reminding us that she is a truly great singer and a stylish pianist. https://t.co/qBLG6gJkwd

name: NewYorker
text: Why did American policing get so big, so fast? The answer, mainly, is slavery. https://t.co/73AHP1FTSU

name: NewYorker
text: “Exciting Times,” a new novel by the 28-year-old Irish author Naoise Dolan, is an examination of sex, queerness, self-sabotage, power, and privilege. Unavoidably, Dolan has drawn comparisons to Sally Rooney. https://t.co/AghpCe1KjW

name: NewYorker
text: Why does a substantial portion of Gen Z want Harry Styles to punch them in the face? https://t.co/jmxlHutFC6

name: NewYorker
text:
Since 2007, Michael Rakowitz has been making art about looted artifacts and cultural expropriation, offering a critique of the art institutions that made the removal of Iraqi heritage possible. 
https://t.co/9HmpaARIwd

name: NewYorker
text: "I couldn’t help overhearing what Q and his pretty companion were saying to each other. It was a fairly complicated matter. I gave up trying to read and listened to them." Flash fiction by Haruki Murakami. https://t.co/WyQuBTbHBk

name: NewYorker
text:
Even after the civil-rights movement changed Mississippi and America, the state held on to the Confederate flag, asserting that it had everything to do with heritage and nothing to do with hate.
https://t.co/qrF2BI5K2P

name: NewYorker
text: "We wanted it to start from inside the system." The filmmakers behind Netflix’s new docuseries “Immigration Nation” discuss their unique access to Immigrations and Customs Enforcement. #NewYorkerRadio https://t.co/RDEKu3nrcu

name: NewYorker
text: “The Song Is You,” a short film directed by Andrea Longacre-White, is at once charming, unnerving, and politically sharp, David Remnick writes. Watch here. https://t.co/LG4SRbd8At

name: NewYorker
text: Too often in Black politics, symbolism has stood in for making a meaningful difference in the lives of Black people. https://t.co/MQn5H4gJCp

name: NewYorker
text:
Why were the killers of Ahmaud Arbery allowed to walk free until the shooting became a national scandal? And what does the failure to prosecute say about the power of district attorneys? #NewYorkerRadio
